title: 107_hr4205
content: The Act is titled the "Affordable Housing Improvements Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Affordable Housing Improvements Act aims to ensure that section 8 rental assistance benefits low-income families in communities with affordable housing needs, allows flexibility in using unused funds for affordable housing development, and supports public housing agencies in jurisdictions lacking affordable housing units. The Affordable Housing Improvements Act aims to develop affordable housing in communities without supplanting existing section 8 program funds and promote quality housing for low-income families. SEC. 3. AUTHORITY TO TRANSFER UNUSED SECTION 8 RENTAL ASSISTANCE AMOUNTS. Section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow the transfer of unused tenant-based assistance to the HOME and Public Housing Capital Fund Programs for eligible activities. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to permit the transfer of unused tenant-based assistance to the HOME and Public Housing Capital Fund Programs for eligible activities. The transferred amounts must be used within an 18-month period from approval of the transfer request, which must comply with specific requirements outlined by the Secretary. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows the transfer of unused tenant-based assistance to the HOME and Public Housing Capital Fund Programs. The transfer request must include information on affordable housing needs, conditions, and availability in the geographical area served by the agency. The transfer request for unused tenant-based assistance under the United States Housing Act of 1937 must include vacancy rates, waiting lists for rental assistance, return rates for vouchers, compliance with laws and regulations, efforts to assist eligible families, and a proposal for utilizing the unused assistance. The request for unused tenant-based assistance under the United States Housing Act of 1937 must include vacancy rates, waiting lists, return rates for vouchers, compliance with laws, efforts to assist families, and a proposal for utilizing the assistance. Requests must be submitted to the Secretary within 60 days of the fiscal year end, along with a proposal for how the assistance will be used under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act or for eligible activities with Capital Fund amounts. Additional information or certifications may be required by the Secretary. The Secretary will determine whether to approve a request for unused tenant-based assistance from a public housing agency within 30 days. The transfer of assistance can only be authorized if it will be used in accordance with specific sections of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The Secretary will approve requests for unused tenant-based assistance within 30 days if it meets specific requirements of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, including use within 18 months. Definitions for terms like 'applicable participating jurisdiction' are provided. The term 'applicable participating jurisdiction' refers to a participating jurisdiction within the geographical area served by a public housing agency. The term 'leasing rate' is the ratio of leased dwelling units to reserved units for tenant-based assistance. The term 'reserved units' refers to the number of units reserved for a specific amount of budget authority. The term 'unused tenant-based assistance' refers to budget authority for tenant-based assistance that remains unused and can be reallocated to other agencies based on leasing rates. SEC. 4. USE OF TRANSFERRED AMOUNTS UNDER HOME INVESTMENT PARTNERSHIPS PROGRAM. The HOME Investment Trust Fund can now be used for affordable rental housing and homeownership within the jurisdiction of the transferring public housing agency. Additionally, targeting requirements under the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act have been amended. The National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include provisions for unused public housing agency amounts in the HOME Investment Trust Fund. This includes requirements for rental assistance to families with incomes not exceeding 30 percent of the median family income for the area. The National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include provisions for rental assistance to families with incomes not exceeding 30 percent of the median family income for the area, with adjustments for smaller and larger families as necessary. The National Affordable Housing Act is amended to include provisions for rental assistance to low-income families, ensuring that a certain percentage of funds are invested in dwelling units occupied by households meeting specific income criteria. The amendments made by this Act apply to tenant-based assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 from fiscal year 2003 onwards. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must issue final regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment to implement these changes.
